title: 104_hr2565
content: The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include a ban on political action committees' activities in House of Representatives elections. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits entities other than individuals or political committees from making contributions or expenditures to influence elections for House Representatives, Delegates, or Resident Commissioners. The definition of a political committee includes candidate campaign committees, party committees at various levels, and local committees receiving over $5,000 in contributions annually. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 sets limitations on contributions and expenditures made by political committees. Amendments include changes to the thresholds for contributions and expenditures during a calendar year. Additionally, candidate's committees are subject to regulations regarding financing and control by candidates or officeholders. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include regulations on authorized committees controlled by candidates or officeholders. Political committees supporting multiple candidates cannot be designated as authorized committees, except for the national committee of a party supporting a presidential candidate. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits political committees established by corporations, labor organizations, or trade associations from making contributions to candidates or their authorized committees if a certain limitation is not in effect. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits political committees supported by corporations, labor organizations, or trade associations from contributing over $1,000 to any candidate or their authorized committee for an election. SEC. 2. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ELECTION LIMITATION ON CONTRIBUTIONS FROM PERSONS OTHER THAN LOCAL INDIVIDUAL RESIDENTS. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to limit contributions from non-local individual residents for candidates running for Representative in Congress. Candidates exceeding this limit must pay a penalty to the Commission. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 limits contributions from non-local individual residents for candidates running for Representative in Congress. Candidates who exceed this limit must pay a penalty to the Commission, which includes the excess contributions plus a civil penalty determined by the Commission. Additionally, candidates accepting contributions exceeding the limitation for a different period must pay an amount equal to 3 times the excess contributions to the Commission. Each report must include a certification that contributions do not exceed the limitation. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 imposes expenditure and personal contribution limitations for candidates running for the House of Representatives. Candidates are restricted to spending $600,000 for a general election, including any related primary election, and personal contributions are capped at $100,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 imposes expenditure and personal contribution limitations for House of Representatives candidates. The Act now includes a new provision that prohibits candidates from making personal contributions exceeding $100,000 for a general election, including any related primary election. Additionally, there is a ban on independent expenditures in House of Representatives elections. A new provision prohibits candidates from making personal contributions exceeding $100,000 for a general election, including any related primary election. There is also a ban on independent expenditures in House of Representatives elections. Additionally, there is a ban on soft money in elections for federal office. SEC. 6 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 by banning soft money in federal elections. SEC. 7 addresses franking provisions. In an election year, House Members are restricted from mailing mass mailings as franked mail postmarked before the Tuesday after the 1st Monday in November. This restriction does not permit mailing any mass mailing that would be prohibited by other laws or regulations. This restriction does not permit mailing any mass mailing that would be prohibited by other laws or regulations. The definition of a mass mailing is further amended for Members of the House, with specific changes to the number of mailings allowed and the purposes for which they can be sent. The amendments made by this section regarding mass mailings by House Members take effect on the date of enactment of the Act. Mail sent before this date is considered separately from mail sent after.
